body:
I don't see syncthing as a zero latency mirroring application.

There is a cost associated with starting a scan, so I am not sure that doing on every file change is feasible, so I think you are simply using the wrong tool.

Well, I mean, that’s a trade off that might be legitimate, so I don’t think we need to enforce it. There will presumably be some natural batching anyway for changes happening while we’re scanning the previous changes.
I fear that the behaviour will not be what the user expects, given scanning and syncing is exclusive.

I think I'm missing some important pieces of the puzzle. I thought that the mode of operation is:

1. receive change notification
2. receive change notification
3. receive change notification
[...]
4. when no change received for `fsWatcherDelayS` seconds:
  a. scan files for which a notification was received
  b. synchronize

If that's correct (which might totally not be, I haven't dug deep into the sources), then the cost of 4a is proportional to the number of files, and unless one types _real_ fast, I don't foresee many saves in less than one second. :) Also, `fsWatcherDelayS` is per-folder, so it would seem safe to give the option.

Again, writing all this without deep knowledge of the internals.

FYI, there's at least one project that is relying on Syncthing for remote development: https://github.com/okteto/okteto. (I did try it but ran into the latency issue.)

There is a some cost for setting up step 4, getting database snapshots, locks etc. With "no delay", that cost would have to be paid on every file change., potentially introducing enough latency that dropping the delay below 1 second wouldn't make much difference.

I did a quick test by applying a one-line hack in `aggregator.go` to switch from seconds to milliseconds, and left `fsWatcherDelayS` at the default value of 10. I must say it works even better than I hoped. This is the effect when sharing the syncthing source repo with a remote machine (on the left) which is ~30ms ping time away:

![screencast](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19322/127748755-3b6dd587-132d-4460-8922-421741b239f4.gif)

As I said, just a hack, no pretense of contributable code:

```diff
 }
 
 func (a *aggregator) updateConfig(folderCfg config.FolderConfiguration) {
-	a.notifyDelay = time.Duration(folderCfg.FSWatcherDelayS) * time.Second
+	a.notifyDelay = time.Duration(folderCfg.FSWatcherDelayS) * time.Millisecond
 	a.notifyTimeout = notifyTimeout(folderCfg.FSWatcherDelayS)
 	a.folderCfg = folderCfg
 }
```

Changing that variable to be milliseconds is not "free", as it requires a config migration, and the old field will have to be present in the config structure potentially forever.

Allowing value of zero is not sensible, as if you did something like a git checkout k8s project, it would end up consuming unreasonable amount of resources.

Personally, I'd say that perhaps maintaining a fork for your use case is the right way forward here, but that is my opinion, and other maintainers might have a different view.
It might be mostly free to change the type to float and keep the seconds unit.

> Allowing value of zero is not sensible, as if you did something like a git checkout k8s project, it would end up consuming unreasonable amount of resources.

I changed

https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/0126188ba7c652da06199a4c9264d67d6cda786f/lib/config/folderconfiguration.go#L191-L194

to

```go
 if f.FSWatcherDelayS < 0 { 
 	f.FSWatcherEnabled = false 
 	f.FSWatcherDelayS = 10 
 } 
```

and then compiled a custom build. I created a new folder, set the watcher delay to `0`, and then ran a piece of software inside it that creates and modifies thousands of files very quickly. As expected, Syncthing was picking up the changes almost immediately as they were taking place. I didn't experience any extraordinary resource usage though (on Ryzen 4350G with a mid-range SSD). The Web GUI was indeed going a little crazy, changing the folder status back and forth almost constantly.

Nevertheless, would it bring any harm if a value of `0` was simply allowed for special cases like the one described here? Syncthing already allows much more dangerous custom configuration (e.g. disable fsync, etc.). There is no danger in this one except for potentially higher resource usage, right?

**Edit**:

There is also this part of the code:

https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/37d0ba16603a71f15b5ebdc8485d3bc0de65615c/lib/watchaggregator/aggregator.go#L456-L473

Currently, with the shortest possible watch delay of `1`, the deletion delay is `6`, right? Will deletion delay also become `0` when watch delay is set to `0`?
Logically it should. I think this is fine. You'll miss out on rename optimizations and whatnot, but if you're tuning this for Ultimate Speed(tm) then that's what you're tuning for.

issue.title: lib/config: Allow sub-second watcher delay (fixes #7859)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
Allow the watcher delay to take fractional values, effectively allowing
for much shorter delays. The minimum value is limited at 0.01, which
effectively translates to 10ms. This is required in order to guarantee
that there is still enough time to aggregate multiple single change
events.

Signed-off-by: Tomasz Wilczyński <twilczynski@naver.com>

body:
Crap. I'm using syncthing for the same reason as the issue author. I've spent several hours setting up syncthing on my local PC and on my remote server through Docker, and only now do I find out it's too slow for my use case, it takes 8-9 seconds from I hit save until the remote file is updated.

Was this issue ever resolved? Can I tune syncthing to be faster? (Preferably sub-second?)

---

EDIT: Ah, I'm a sloppy reader, I just now noticed the `fsWatcherDelayS` setting. I reduced it to 1 and it drastically improved things. There's still a 1-2 second delay, though. Is there currently anything that can be done to reduce it?

Unfortunately, no. In the linked PR, I got stuck on code related to usage reporting and wasn't able to finish it. Someone with better Go skills should probably be able to accomplish this quite easily.

At the moment, the value of `1` will allow Syncthing to sync new files and modifications in 1 second, and deletions in 6 seconds.

There. You'll have to configure it manually in the config file though, because the advanced config editor doesn't accept floats and I couldn't figure out why in a reasonable amount of time (it's an `<input type=number>` 🤷 )

> There. You'll have to configure it manually in the config file though, because the advanced config editor doesn't accept floats and I couldn't figure out why in a reasonable amount of time (it's an `<input type=number>` 🤷 )

I think this may be browser-dependent? I've just tried in Chromium, and I can input numbers like `0.1` or `0.01` with no problems (and they do save properly into config).

By the way, thank you very much for completing the PR 🙂.

Woah, this was quite the surprise. Thank you both. :)

About the `<input>`: I couldn't immediately find it (happy to have a look — can you point me to it?) but usually fiddling with the `min` and `step` parameters tames float-related matters.

It's in the auto generated advanced editor:

https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/2bcaa17fc3233ecf95011233be5d19b9c9b40273/gui/default/syncthing/settings/advancedSettingsModalView.html#L90

The `inputTypeFor(...)` method returns `number` for all numeric inputs. I suspect the rest of the problem is somewhere in angular, which I'm not interested in trying to debug. Also, making an exception for this field specifically is tricky given how all this is auto generated from the actual config json.

Please reveal shortDelayMultiplicator in Advanced settings. 
Also +1 to subsecond delays.

Having forceful scans (not fsWatcher) writes 57 bytes each scan (every second) into "indexed*/*.log", While fsWatcher writes 109 bytes every 36 seconds. Would also be nice to disable these pointless? writes at all.

Not related to issue but having some buffering (1-10s) is hugely beneficial when many small files sent to another device and another device immediately deletes them because each file issues ~4-5 kb writes to "indexed*/*.log".
